Message.Msg: The home-built J-15 fighter jet took off from and landed on the Liaoning, a reconditioned Soviet-era vessel from Ukraine which only came into service in September this year. http://www.cnbc.com/id/49954940

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: The USA has 11 aircraft carriers, with three more under construction. China's Liaoning is an old Soviet carrier launched in 1988.

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Poordumb, While it sounds impressive to have eleven aircraft carriers with three more coming, there are today only three "underway" (in operation) - two at the Indian Ocean/Persian Gulf (5th fleet) and the other at Sea of Japan (7th fleet). The Navy's website gives the fleet status indicating that, overall, only 36% of U.S. naval vessels are deployed. An "aircraft carrier system availability" requirement of "11 for 3" is absurd. This administration is purposely underutilizing our navy - as Romney accurately pointed out in the presidential debates. Why is that? The lack of support to the Mediterranean is a contributing reason that the events unfolded in Bengahazi as they did. And, yet, folks voted this man back in office for more of what he is able to do or purposely not do for our nation's security. BB

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: You sound like the classic armchair general (or admiral in this case) in addition to the classic street-corner preacher. You are a dabbler in many expertises. Do you know how many ships accompany each carrier in a carrier battle group? Do you know how many of those escort/support ships are nuclear-powered? Do you know how many sailors staff the average carrier battle group? Do you know how much "sea room" each needs? Can you post a link to any admirals actually asking that more carriers be deployed to world hot spots?

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Yes. They probably need carriers deployed in case the Vatican Navy or Royal Air Force of Chad needs scaring. We need at least 2,000 carrier groups. Or 3,000.

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Chris, You sound like you are sitting at your armchair as well. You cite "sea room". It must not be a significant issue as Obama deployed two aircraft acrriers at the same time to the Persian Gulf which represents less than 1% of the total ocean accessible waters. The admirals report to the commander-in-chief. So, which admiral is going to ask for more than the President is wanting to deploy? Apparently, one admiral (Rear Adm. Charles M. Gaouette) got in hot water and was fired for just that as a result of Benghazi. Obama had two of the three "underway" deployed to the Persian Gulf on 9/11/2012; the other in the Pacific. Three carriers "underway" with eight at port is a monumental waste. The question begged is, if this is all that is required, then why do we need three more? The reason for deployment is to support and be ready for "hot spots". Ported carriers have a 90 day readiness requirement. Kind of slow. The Persian Gulf 2 carrier deployment was overkill. The Pacific Fleet one carrier deployment is under-kill - given: North Korea and South Korea disputes, island disputes between Japan and China and island disputes between Taiwan, China, and the Philippines. Then there is the Mediterranean: nothing, no carrier support. And yet, there is Libya, Egypt, Gaza, Israel, Syria, - all in flames in one form or another. And NATO partner Turkey requesting support. It is as if Obama is driving towards a "hands off" policy in the Middle East - save for ridiculous oversight of Iran. What did he say about Israel recently (during the dispute with Gaza)? Now read this carefully, "As for security, every state has the right to self-defense, and Israel must be able to defend itself – BY ITSELF – against any threat." That doesn't sound like Obama intends to "have Israel's back". And Obama has made sure of it with the bizarre carrier operations and deployments. BB

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Standard Navy doctrine for the last 3 decades has been 1/3 in refit 1/3 in training/work up and 1/3 deployed. Note that for the last few years the deployment has been higher which has meant less refit/maintenance which has started to catch up with us, the Nimitz did not deploy as scheduled because of a mechanical breakdown which is why there are only 3 instead of 4 deployed.

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Tech, The greater number of deployments correspond to the conditions so that the 30 year old doctrine is likely not adequate - if that is even deemed true today. The Fleet Response Plan (2001) as indicated in the "Navy Transformational Roadmap" on the Navy's website, states, "The requirement to be able to swiftly defeat aggression in overlapping conflicts called for in the 2001 QDR has necessitated a focus on developing new surge capabilities to complement and capitalize on our current competency in providing immediately employable forward-deployed naval forces." Further, "With refined maintenance, modernization, manning and training processes, as well as fully-funded readiness accounts, the Fleet can consistently sustain a level of at least 6 surge-capable carrier strike groups, with two additional strike groups able to deploy within approximately 90 days of an emergency order." Three does not sound like six. Forget for a moment what are the traditions and blather coming from some position document. Where are they needed? Two in the Pacific (Japan, Koreas, China, Philippines). One in the Mediterranean (more for the Middle East). And one in the Indian Ocean and one in the Persian Gulf. At least five. Presumably, that is the logic behind the 2001 FRP. BB

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: The key word is surge. We have been deploying our armed forces in surge mode for too long and it has started to catch up to us. Carriers and soldiers cannot sustain the level of deployment we have been asking for the last 10 years without rest refit and maintenance. Now we are in a situation where maintenance issues are starting to seriously inhibit our ability to deploy naval forces just when we need them. And, trust me, our Army and Marine troops are worn out from too many deployments with too little rest. That's the problem with going into wars without clear goals and exit strategies.

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: As I look out my bay window and I can see the Nimitz pointed directly at me as it sits docked at Naval Station Everett. It just came back last week after doing training and carrier qualifications for a soon to come deployment. I have heard nothing about the Nimitz being out of service because of mechanical problems or malfunctions. In fact they recieved high praise for their current efficiency and readiness.

Topic.Title: China lands fighter jet on new carrier in show of force

Message.Msg: Nov 23,2012: WASHINGTON — The Navy said Wednesday it will temporarily shrink its aircraft carrier presence in the Persian Gulf area from two to one because of a mechanical problem with the USS Nimitz, a nuclear carrier based in Everett. The Nimitz was scheduled to deploy in January to relieve the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower, but that will be put off until summer in order to complete repairs to its propulsion system. The problem was found while the ship was doing pre-deployment maneuver
